_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.   Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of Wabash Valley Service Company are committed to the 
prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release 
should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the McLeansboro Fire Department, 
Hamilton County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any 
release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. 

2. The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at  RR 2 Dahlgren IL, is the storage 
and distribution of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, 
and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and 
handling system consists of 1-18,000 & 1-12,000 gallon storage tank(s), loading risers, 
associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized 
facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 344,000 
pounds, this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse 
tanks.

3. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable 
state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by 
The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the 
standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 
1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these 
regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention 
program.  

4. Five year accident history. 

The following is a list of accidental

releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have occurred at the facility:
- March 29, 2001: Lost 200 gal of NH3 from a nurse tank in the form of a vapor cloud - due to theft and vandalism - to our knowledge, no offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage occurred. - May 5, 2001: Lost 1000 gal of NH3 from a nurse tank, in the form of a vapor cloud - due to theft and vandalism - to our knowledge, no offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage or environmental damage occurred.

5. The emergency response program.

The facility has:
- a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
- provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-
know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the 
McLeansboro Fire Department and Hamilton County LEPC and request that they respond 
to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire 
department and LEPC.

6. Planned changes to improve safety. 

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are 
performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety 
recommendations for implementation at this time.
